title: 114_hr5100
content: The Act titled "At-Risk Youth Medicaid Protection Act of 2016" aims to protect at-risk youth under Medicaid. The Social Security Act is amended to ensure that states cannot terminate medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates but may suspend coverage during their incarceration. The Social Security Act is amended to prevent states from terminating medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates. Coverage can be suspended during incarceration, but must be restored upon release without requiring a new application, unless eligibility requirements are no longer met. States must process applications for medical assistance from juvenile inmates in public institutions. The Social Security Act is amended to protect medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates in public institutions. A juvenile is defined as under 21 years old or meeting specific criteria. An eligible juvenile is one who was eligible for medical assistance before incarceration or becomes eligible while in a public institution. The Social Security Act is amended to protect medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates in public institutions, ensuring continuity of eligibility before adjudication or sentencing. This does not change the exclusion from medical assistance for inmates of public institutions under section 1905(a) of the Act. The amendments to the Social Security Act protect medical assistance for eligible juvenile inmates in public institutions, ensuring coverage before adjudication or sentencing. The effective date for these changes is 1 year after the enactment of the Act, with exceptions for states requiring legislation to meet the new requirements. The State plan is not considered to fail compliance with the requirements of the Social Security Act solely based on not meeting additional requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the first regular session of the State legislature following the enactment of the Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is treated as a separate regular session of the State legislature.
